generationDetails.description: Questions mapped to NSW Stage 2 outcomes and lesson foci. Eight 1-mark multiple-choice and four 2-mark short-answer items created (16 marks total).

questions.question: Which sequence correctly lists Earth’s layers from the surface moving inward?

answers.content: Crust → Mantle → Outer core → Inner core
answers.explanation: This is the accepted scientific order from the outside to the centre.

answers.content: Mantle → Crust → Inner core → Outer core
Crust → Outer core → Mantle → Inner core
Mantle → Outer core → Crust → Inner core

questions.question: Why is the inner core solid even though it is extremely hot?

answers.content: It is cooled by surrounding water.
Intense pressure keeps the iron–nickel alloy in a solid state.
answers.explanation: High pressure overrides the effect of temperature.

answers.content: It is made entirely of rock.
There is no heat source near the inner core.

questions.question: Describe one similarity and one difference between weathering and erosion.

answers.content: Both processes change rocks; weathering breaks rocks apart in place, whereas erosion moves the broken material elsewhere.

questions.rubric: 1 mark for stating a valid similarity (e.g. both involve rock change). 1 mark for a clear difference that distinguishes breaking from movement.

questions.question: Which agent of weathering is directly involved when plant roots grow into cracks in rocks and split them apart?

answers.content: Wind
Moving water
Plants
answers.explanation: Root growth is a biological agent of weathering.

answers.content: Temperature change

questions.question: Tectonic plates get stuck against each other until the stress is released. What natural event does this sudden release of energy cause?

answers.content: A tsunami
An earthquake
answers.explanation: The lesson models this with a Mars bar.

answers.content: A volcanic eruption
Weathering

questions.question: During the Mars-bar model, what happened to the ‘crust’ when the two halves were pushed together, and what does this demonstrate about real earthquakes?

answers.content: The chocolate cracked and buckled, demonstrating how Earth’s crust fractures and deforms at plate boundaries during an earthquake.

questions.rubric: 1 mark for describing the cracking/buckling. 1 mark for linking this to crustal behaviour in earthquakes.

questions.question: Which immediate landscape change can result from a volcanic eruption?

answers.content: Formation of new land as lava cools and solidifies
answers.explanation: Cooling lava can add fresh rock, creating new land.

answers.content: Lowering of sea level worldwide
Removal of the Earth’s atmosphere
Permanent stop to tectonic plate motion

questions.question: Using a causal connective, explain a positive knock-on effect that fertile volcanic ash can have on nearby communities.

answers.content: Because volcanic ash is rich in minerals, soils become more fertile, so farmers can grow larger and healthier crops.

questions.rubric: 1 mark for correct use of a causal connective. 1 mark for explaining a realistic positive effect tied to fertility.

questions.question: In the moving-water erosion investigation, which variable was deliberately changed to test its effect?

answers.content: Amount of sand in each tray
Volume of water poured
Angle (slope) of the tray
answers.explanation: Only the slope differed; all other factors were kept the same.

answers.content: Length of the river channel

questions.question: What conclusion best matches the results of the investigation when the steepest slope was tested?

answers.content: Less erosion occurred because water moved slowly.
More erosion occurred because faster-moving water carried more sand.
answers.explanation: Steeper slope → faster flow → greater erosive force.

answers.content: No erosion occurred on any slope.
Erosion was the same on all slopes regardless of speed.

questions.question: Which term describes the process of broken rock being dropped or settled in a new place after erosion?

answers.content: Deposition
Melting
Compaction
Radiation

questions.question: State one way Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Peoples’ practices help habitats to survive and explain why it is effective.

answers.content: Cultural burning reduces undergrowth, so it lowers the intensity of wildfires and promotes new plant growth that supports animal habitats.

questions.rubric: 1 mark for naming a correct practice (e.g. cultural burning). 1 mark for explaining how it supports habitat survival.
